subject: Investing
title: What Earnings Per Share Tells You
description: A quick win: understand What Earnings Per Share Tells You.

hook.text: Company A earns $10 billion. Company B earns $1 billion. Which is a better investment? You can't tell yet.

buildup.text: EPS â€” earnings per share â€” divides total profit by shares outstanding. It normalizes profit for comparison.

discovery.text: If Company A has 50 billion shares, its EPS is $0.20. Company B with 100 million shares has EPS of $10.

twist.text: Companies can boost EPS by buying back shares. Fewer shares means higher EPS, even with flat profits.

climax.text: Diluted EPS includes stock options and convertibles. It shows the worst case for existing shareholders.

punchline.text: EPS makes profit personal: how much the company earned for each share you own.

quiz.question: How can a company increase EPS without growing profits?
options: By buying back shares to reduce shares outstanding
